title: Bizarre slime that looks like 'bright yellow caviar-looking eggs' is found on the pavement
text:
A mysterious lump of slime spotted on the pavement near some plants has left a woman scratching her head.

She described the discovery in Redcliffe Peninsula, north of Brisbane, as 'bright yellow caviar-looking eggs'.

The stumped woman claimed the lump kept expanding in size and changing colour throughout the day.

A woman has stumbled upon a mysterious lump (pictured) on the pavement near plants

She took to Facebook to ask residents if they had seen anything like it before.

One user likened the lump to left over pancakes, while the another said it looked like cooked chicken breast.

A user suggested the slime resembled an omelette.

An environmental scientist from the Australian Museum told Yahoo News Australia the bizarre find was dog vomit slime mould and is also commonly known as 'scrambled egg fungus'.

The slime, which resembles a dog's stomach contents, quickly changes in size, colour and shape, according to the Master Gardener plant website.

The colour can change from white to yellow and pinkish brown, while the texture can appear to be foamy-looking or dried up.

The lump described as 'bright yellow caviar looking eggs' was dog vomit slime mould (stock image)

Slime moulds are commonly found in moist, shady areas with hardwood mulch and dead leaves.

The mould thrives in moisture and develops anytime from late spring through to Autumn.

While many are grossed about by the mould's appearance, it is harmless to people, plants and pets.

But the dusty spores can irritate people with allergies or asthma.
description: She described the discovery in Queensland's Redcliffe peninsula as 'bright yellow caviar looking eggs'.
authors: Paula Ahillon For Daily Mail Australia
